A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: J.F. Paul Borschel

2. Your address: Canora Sask.

3. Date: July 9th, 1956

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Langenau, Kreiss Corlitz, Province Silesia, Germany.

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Johann Friedrich Borschel, Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and Year): July 1893

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Lived in no other place

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.): I was 18 years old.

9. What were your reasons for coming West? To get the owner of a farm.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?): An agent in Fortit, Germany gave me a book published by the Government of Canada on the free lands of Canada in the North West Territories.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Some thought we were making a good decision. Others thought we should not go. But the whole village all wished us God's speed.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? No, our whole family came out. Father, mother, 4 brothers and sisters. One brother remained in Germany.

13. What means of transportation did you use? We left Bury which was our nearest railway station by train to Hamburg where we boarded our ship the Rickhoven which carried us to Montreal, where we boarded the P.R.R. Calgarian Train which took us to Winnipeg where we boarded the Macdonald Northwestern Railway which took us to Yorkton.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

The first and most outstanding incident and also the most exciting of the journey was on board of the ship. We entered the Gulf Stream. Towards evening our officer told us tomorrow we will see the ice bergs. About 10 o'clock in the evening it was very dark. I was sitting on a bench below deck, when an awful crash came, then another and another. There was a fearful quietness. All at once the jarring of the ship's ships together with screams from the people made terrible. The ship had struck an ice berg. Luckily it pulled off. It was however badly badly in and had a while but was able to proceed.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We stayed in the immigration shed in Yorkton. The two oldest sisters went to Winnipeg to work. Weymington and Owen. The two oldest brothers and myself went to build a house on the homestead. Father, mother and three young children stayed in Yorkton until we had a house built.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Twenty miles north of Yorkton on Sect. 20 Tp. 28 Rg 4 W.4th Mer.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I never worked outside of Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Before coming out, I studied on the College, worked on my father's farm and for my oldest brother who was a contractor. After coming out here, I proved up my homestead and worked for my father. The first winter I worked in the bush cutting logs for a saw mill. Later I worked for Ranchers. On survey parties and building roads for the Government. In 1898 I cut 500 telephone poles for the first telephone line built out of Yorkton.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
Yes quite a number, but many went back again. Those who stayed are now settled all over Canada.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
Brother-in-Law
Mrs. Francis with wife and one son came out in 1909 and settled in Canora. Where is she now? Family are living yet.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
When we came to Yorkton after such a long journey over land and sea, Yorkton was the end station of the Manitoba North Western Railway Company consisting of two stores, a hotel, a livery barns, a post office and some dwellings stuck up in the prairie. It was one of those nice summer days the whole prairie was full of flowers, the whole village was at the station to greet us amongst them were two members of the Canadian North West Mounted Police force, of whom I had read before and who were considered as the finest police force in the world. This made us feel that we were wanted here and would be able to make a home.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
The first eight years I came to Canada I did not much travelling. We went to Yorkton perhaps once in a month to buy provisions etc. Yorkton was 20 miles. The first year we made the trips with oxen. Later we had horses. Going to church, which was held in the neighborhood. There were many people in the country and those in the country were mostly single young men. The Ministers there always held church where a family was blessed with young ladies of marriageable age.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Very often.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, how many came?

Yes, we came to Saskatchewan because of our recommendation. We came in 1909 and settled in Canada. We had a son and family are living yet.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

When we came to Canada, we had a son and family are living yet.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to report?

The first eight years was very hard and we had horses. The first year we needed two trips with our horses across 10 miles. Going to church, which was held in the schoolhouse, was very hard. People in the community used to bring their horses to church. We were mostly single young men and women in the community who helped each other before a farm was blessed with young families of marriages age.
In this way, the minister was sure of a good attendance. The people came on foot, on horseback, with wagons and buggies. One time I was to church, when a sleek team of Black Oxen came along pulling a wagon with 4 young men and a lady along.

When we had a picnic, people came from all over the country sometimes from a distance of twenty miles.

The most travelling I did was when I worked on the Land Survey. In 1897, I worked for Mr. Duberger L.S.P. and later until 1900 I worked for Mr. J.D. Belanger L.S.P. Mr. Duberger was instructed by the Dominion Government to survey the line between Range three and four north until he strikes the Saskatchewan River. Mr. Belanger surveyed the Second Meridian and Base Line north of No. 40.

We used wagons when we could, in the bushy country we used pack horses. In swamps where we could use no horses at all, we had to pack it all on our own backs, and in winter we had each man a sleigh. When we started out these sleighs were loaded quite heavy as it was figured that each man had to load enough provision to last him till spring for pulling the instruments etc. We had a sled with 4 dogs. The dogs however were not much help if the party is out all winter as a dog will pull no more than he needs for food for himself in four months.
In this the minister was sure of a good attendance.

The people came on foot or horseback, with wagons and mules. One time I was to church, when we slept two men of Black River coming along pulling a wagon with 4 yams man and a lady along.

When we had a big picnic people came from all over the country sometimes from a distance of twenty miles.

We went travelling I did not work when I worked on the land survey. In 1897 I worked for Mr. Belanger & Co., and later until 1900 I worked for Mr. F. Belanger & Co. Mr. Belanger was interested in the Dominion Government for surveying the line between Range three and four north until he struck the second Missouri River. Mr. Belanger came to the Second Missouri and Base Line north to 40.

We used wagons where we could, in the bushy country we used pack horses, but whenever we could use no horses at all. We had to pack it all on our own backs, and whatever we hid back meant a slough. Mr. Duberg was instructed by the Dominion Government to survey the line between Range three and four north until he strikes the Saskatchewan River. Mr. Belanger surveyed the Second Meridian and Base line north No. 40.

When we started out these sleighs were loaded quite heavy as it was figured that each man had to load enough provision to last him till spring. The dogs however were not much help if the party is out all winter as dog will pull no more than he needs for food for himself in four months.

The people came on foot or horseback, with wagons and buggies. One time I was to church, when the sleigh team of Black Oxen came along pulling a wagon with 4 young men and a lady along.

When we had a picnic, people came from all over the country sometimes from a distance of twenty miles.

The worst travelling I did was when I worked on the Grand Survey. In 1897, I worked for Mr. Belanger & Co., and later until 1900 I worked for Mr. J. D. Belanger & Co., who Belanger may have been.

By the Dominion Government to survey the line between Range three and four, north until the thirty-first parallel.

The second Abominian and Base Village near the 40th parallel.

We used wagons where we could, in the bushy country, we used pack horses, two wagons when we could use no horses at all. We had to pack it all our own backs, and when we had to pack it, we had quite heavy as times figured that each of our sleds had to load enough provisions to last him till spring.

For pulling the instruments yet, we had a sled with 4 dogs. The dogs however were not much help if the snow is out all winter and will pull no more than he needs for food for himself in four months.
25. When was the first car used in the community? In 1911.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   I did not own any until 1915, a Chevrolet.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? From 1893 to 1905 Yorkton 20 miles from home, after 1905 Cawra I lived right in Cawra.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Cawra came into being in 1904, it was closer.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? About once a month.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   I had a Route on the farm Peter Wilson, he went with his wife to town regularly every Saturday to sell butter, eggs, etc.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   In 1895, Garden Seeds, Harness, Small Machinery, about 10%. Yes later we bought about 20%.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? 1908 The Government Telephone Co.

   We were 6 boys each wanted to get some land. Here we were offered 160 acres. We had our mind made up to stay here before we left Germany.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

In the hard years from 1873 to 1896 all the families who had come out prior to 95 went back to Germany because they did not think they could make a living here.

There was a whole German settlement west where Tolietz is situated. They left and settled near Humboldt. They wanted to be with their own people.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

In the years from 1898 to 1915 many Americans settled in the Canora District. They brought power machinery and big outfits for farming with them and farmed in a bigger scale. In the 30's all these farmers sold out and went back to the U.S.A. Many young Canadians went away in those years also, but returned.

At present I am Hon. President and Five Member of the Canora Agricultural Society.

Life Member of the Canora and District Chamber of Commerce and Hon. Member of the Ukrainian Power Society.

Mr. R.W. Cummings, James Charters, Harry Bausman, my brothers Herman, Ernest and myself organized the Canora Agricultural Society. Mr. Cummings was the first President and I was the first Secretary. My brother Ernest built the first Livery Barn in Canora.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Mrs. Wilson Allan was the first store keeper. He named the Town Canora after the first Canadian Northern Railway Co.-Catto-Ra.

Tolietz 1/2 south of Canora is named after the town we came from in Germany. Mikado received its name from the Railway Officials. The Russian-Japanese war was just on at that time, the Station Amsterdam was named by a Hollander who had a farm close by. Petlock P.O. was named by J. Boivin who settled there in 1890, 7 miles south of Canora today it is called Berrios.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

In the hard years from 1893 to 1896 all the families who had come out prior to '95 went back to Germany because they did not think they could make a living here.

There was a whole German Settlement to east where Gority is situated they left and settled near Humboldt. They wanted to be with their own people.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

In the years from 1898 to 1915 many Americans settled in the Canora District. They brought power machinery and big outfits for farming with them and farmed in a bigger scale. In the 30's all these farmers sold out and went home to the U.S.A. Many young Canadians went away in these years also, but returned.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My Brother was Post Master in Gority from 1903 to 1915 and later Postmaster from Canora from 1907 to 1914. I was appointed J.P. in 1902 and held this Office till 1948. Was Sub-Dominion Land Agent in Canora from 1905 to 1910. Was Councilor from 1907 to 1910, School Trustee from 1911 to 1926. Mayor of the Town of Canora from 1928 to 1932. Trustee of the Canora School Board from 1932 to 1940. I was elected Wheat Pool Delegate for Sub-District 5 District 8 from 1940 to 1941.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "firsts" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible.

(Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

Mr. R.W. Cummings, James Charters, Harry Bausman, my brothers Herman Ernst and myself organized the Canora Agricultural Society. Mr. Cummings was the first President and I was the first Secretary.

My Brother Ernst build the first Poveshell Barn in Canora.

41. The pioneer farmer lived happily in his log cabin on the farm he bought for $150. Later he had a house built on the same land. His children went to the country school, but still attended the school on the farm when the school was closed.

To pay the rent the family had to sell the cow. They needed money to buy food for the winter. They had to move into town because the house in town was much nicer than the one on the farm.

The family moved into town and bought a new house. They were happy living in town because they could go to the movies and have more fun.
41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Question 41.

1) The dwelling of a log shanty with sod roof on the farm where Mother the lady of the farm did the washing with the washboard, by the coal oil lamp, and cooked with the comfortable fitted out with modern fixtures. One day where the lady of the farm only puts in the switch to have electricity provide her with power for most all of her work while she can take it easy.

2) The change from the ox and the horse to the use of the tractor and the auto. In pioneer days wanted to go to town or church when the family in pioneer days wanted to go to town or church a team of oxen later a team of horses were hitched to the wagon but sure today the family acts fast but often having a team of horses hitched to the road. It was slow going and happily they went singing on their way.

3) In pioneer days a boy went to see his best girl on foot or on horseback when time to go home his girl accompanied him generally as far as the gate and here the last secret were exchanged between you and me and the gate post and if he wanted to take her to church or to a picnic he borrowed a buggy.

To-day the boy takes his best girl off in a comfortable auto. In pioneer days ladies thought below their dignity to smoke. In fact a boy visiting his fiancee would not light his pipe before to-day women smoke as much as men.

4) The pioneer farmer lived happily in his log shanty without roof, plaster he had a house with chinglet roof. His children were to the country school. To-day the same house is still on the farm, perhaps mouldered, but the county schoolhouse is still standing in the district to-day the farmer only couples the house when he is grading but which he gets by living in town while children go to more efficient town school he worries not farms from the town by going in and out with his own and such things as horses does right no more he does all his work with power machinery.
41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since first came Meet?

Question 41.

1) The dwelling of a log shanty with sod roof on the farm where by the coal oil lamp was replaced with the washing with the washboard, with modern electric light and comfort of the day where the Lady of the farm only puts in the switch to have electricity provide her with power for most all of her work while she can take it easy.

2) The change from the ox and the horse to the use of the tractor and the auto.

When the family in pioneer days wanted to go to town or church a team of oxen later a team of horses were hitched to the wagon and happily they trotted along the road but sure not fast but often.

3) In pioneer days a boy went to see his best girl on foot or on horseback when time permitted go to town or church. You and me and the gate post and if he wanted to take her to church or to a picnic he borrowed a buggy.

In pioneer days ladies thought low their dignity to smoke in feet a boy visiting his favorite would not light his pipe before first receiving her permission to do so.

To dress women moved so much as man.

4) The pioneer farmer lived happily in his log shanty without roof, after he had a house with chinglet roof. His children went to the country school. To get the best house is still on the farm perhaps modified until the new schoolhouse in the district to be a grandpa's house. The farmer only couples the house when he is comfortable borrowing and threshing his own corn run to the more efficient town school he works his farms on the town by going in and out with his own and enough horses does it all. No more he does all his work with his own power machinery.

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

To become the owner of a farm.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroads or government information?)

An agent in Germany gave us a booklet published by the Government of Canada, on the Free Lands of Canada in the North West Territories.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Some thought we were making a bold decision. Others thought we should not go, but on the whole the village all wished us God's speed.

One brother remained in Germany.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? No, our little family came out, father, mother, 4 brothers and 3 sisters.

13. What means of transportation did you use? We left Tendel, which was our nearest railway station, by train to Hamburg where we boarded our ship, the Pictoumers, which carried us to Montreal. From there we boarded a C.P.R. Colonist train which took us to Winnipeg where we boarded the Manitoba Northern terminus railway, which took us to Yorkton.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.) The first and most outstanding incident and also the most exciting of the journey was on board of the ship. We entered the Gulf Stream. Towards evening our officer told us tomorrow we will see the Ice bergs. About 10 o'clock in the evening it was very dark. I was sitting on a bench outside deck when an awful crash came, then another and another. There was a fearful quietness. All fell silent, then came the sound of the ship together with screams from the people. It was terrible. The Ship had struck an ice berg, but luckily it pulled off. It was, however, badly damaged and had a hole, but was able to proceed.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? We stayed in the Immigration Shed in Yorkton. The two oldest sisters went to Winnipeg to work. We bought a wagon and oxen. The two oldest brothers and myself went to build a house on the homestead. Father, Mother and the three youngest children stayed in Yorkton until we had a house built.

Twenty miles north of Yorkton on Section 30 Tp. 29, Rg. 4, W.2nd No.

16. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. I never lived outside of Saskatchewan.

17. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Before coming out I studied on the College, worked on my father's farm and for my oldest brother who was a contractor. After coming out here I worked in the bush cutting logs for a saw mill. Later I worked for lumber companies and building roads for the Government. In 1899 I got 500 telephone poles for the first telephone line built out of Yorkton.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
Wm. Grams, brother-in-law, with wife and one son came out in 1909 and settled in Canora where his son Egon and family are living yet.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
When we came to Yorkton after such a long journey over land and sea Yorkton was the end Station of the Manitoba North Western Railway Camp, consisting of two stores, one hotel, 2 livery barns, a Post Office and some dwellings stuck up in the prairie. It was one of those nice summer days, the whole prairie was full of flowers. The whole village was at the station to greet us, amongst those were two members of the Canadian North West Mounted Police force of whom I had read before and who were considered the finest Police force in the world. This made us feel that we were wanted here and will be able to make a home.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
The first eight years I came to Canada I did not do much travelling. We went to Yorkton perhaps once a month to buy provisions. Yorkton was 20 miles. The first year we made the trips with oxen. Later we had horses. Going to church, which was held in the neighborhood. There were not many people in the country and those in the country were mostly single young men. The ministers therefore always held church where a family was blessed with young ladies of marriageable age. In this way the minister was sure of a good attendance. The people came on foot, on horseback, with wagons and buggies. One time I was to church when a sleek team of black oxen came along pulling a wagon with 4 young men and a lady along. When we had a picnic people came from all over the country, sometimes from distance of twenty miles.

As most travelling I did was when I worked on the Land Survey. In 1897 I worked for Mr. Duberger, D.L.T., and later until 1900 I worked for Mr. J.A. Belanger, D.L.T. Mr. Duberger was instructed by the Dominion Government to survey the line between range three and four north until he reached the

36. If you or some member of your family have held public offices, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My brother Herman was Post Master in Gorilla from 1903 to 1905, and J.P. and Javer Postmaster from Omora from 1907 to 1914. He was appointed J.P. in 1902 and held this office until 1914. He was also Justice of the Peace in Omora from 1911 to 1914. He was Councilor on town council from 1928 to 1932. Trustee of the Omora School Board from 1928 to 1929. I was elected Wheat Pool Delegate for sub district 5 from 1929 to 1932. At present I am Town President and Life Member of the Omora and District Chamber of Commerce.

Life member of the Omora and District Chamber of Commerce.

In the last years from 1925 to 1926 all the families who had come over prior to 1923 went back to Germany because they did not think they could make a living here.

Was Councilman from 1927 to 1930, School Trustee from 1928 to 1932, Mayor of Gorilla from 1929 to 1930, School Trustee of the Gorilla School Board from 1932 to 1935. I was elected Vice President Delegate to Torrington 5 District (from 1929 to 1930) to 1940. At present I am Hon.
